p: Jinhui Pang is a Lecturer in the Administrative Institute of Information Resources, at Beijing Institute of Technology. She majored in Management Science & Engineering, and received a Doctoral degree in Management Science from the Beijing Institute of Technology, China, in 2008. Her research interests include reliability engineering, game theory, and applications of probability and statistics in various fields.

Xian Zhao is currently a Lecturer in the School of Management & Economics, at Beijing Institute of Technology. He received his Ph.D. in Management Science & Engineering from the Beijing Institute of Technology, China, in 2008. His current research interests are reliability modeling, nano-electronics reliability, applications of probability, and statistics.

details.abstract: <para> Reliability-Based impact (R-impact) factor, defined as the cited half-life multiplied by the citation impact factor, measures both the citation impact and long-lasting impact of published journals. Currently there are several different ways to calculate the citation rates, each with limitations to be improved. This paper provides a new analysis approach for the ranking and citation of published journals. Because cited half-life is the number of publication years from the current year that account for 50% of the current citations published by a journal in its article references, it can evaluate the age of the majority of cited articles. Through using the cited half-life as the sample time variable, we can seek the normalized value of citations and the citable items. This value can avoid the impacts from different journals or different fields. A more radical improvement is suggested in the impact factor, and relative impact factor, which can measure effectively not only the short-time performance of the journals but also the long-time performance. Based on this, relative R-impact (RRI) is proposed to improve R-impact effectively. </para>

context.text: Reliability-Based Citation Impact (R-impact) Factor is an indicator, which is simple but meaningful, defined as the cited half-life multiplied by the citation impact factor [8].
It considers not only how frequently the published papers are cited, known as the citation impact factor, but also gives a lifetime measure for the journal which published the articles [8].
